data.text: Contents
Which areas can facilitate conscious patient self proning ............................................. 7
Introduction

Covid-19 related adult respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) has high mortality and morbidity in ITU despite the technological developments. Our aim is to prevent or delay intubations in the respiratory ward with early proning, allowing time for lung to recover and this can reflect in decreasing mortality.
Scope

This guideline is to provide a simple and effective algorithm which can be followed by everyone on the respiratory wards who are dealing with Covid-19 patients so that proning can be implemented very early in the disease.
Definitions

table_items.text: Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a non- cardiogenic pulmonary oedema and diffuse lung inflammation syndrome that often complicates critical illness
The exchange of carbon dioxide for oxygen by the blood in the lungs.
The alveoli are deflated down to little or no volume.
Is a contagious respiratory and vascular disease.
Is the amount of fluid that is accumulated in the interstitial and alveolar spaces.
Is the process by which oxygen and carbon dioxide move between the bloodstream and the lungs.
Is an abnormally low level of oxygen in the blood. More specifically, it is oxygen deficiency in arterial blood.
Inserting a tube, called an endotracheal tube, through the mouth and then into the airway.
Is a space between structures or objects
Local Safety Standards for Invasive Procedures
The perfusion of the lungs refers to the total volume of blood reaching the pulmonary capillaries in a given time period.
Is a treatment to help a person breathe when they find it difficult or are unable to breathe on their own
Is the difference between the alveolar pressure and the intrapleural pressure in the pleural cavity
Putting a patient in the prone position, or flat on their belly with their chest and face down, rather than on their back.
The distending pressure across the lung is estimated by the transpulmonary pressure, which is defined as the difference between the airway pressure and pleural pressure.

data.text: Role & Responsibilities within the Trust
Clinical Advisory Group
To  ensure  all  policies  and  guidelines  within  the  Medical  division  are  met  the appropriate standards and are well maintained.
Divisional Clinical Director

The  divisional  clinical  director  are  responsible  for  ensuring  that  systems  and processes are in place throughout the divisions to ensure that this document is disseminated appropriately and that monitoring of compliance is undertaken, with remedial  action  implemented  as  appropriate.  In  addition,  the  divisional  clinical directors are responsible for ensuring that all medical staff comply with the contents of the document.
Divisional General Manager

The divisional general manager is responsible for implementing the systems and processes  required  throughout  the  divisions  to  ensure  that  the  document  is disseminated appropriately and that monitoring of compliance is undertaken, with remedial action implemented as appropriate
Associate Director of Nursing Ward Management

The Associate Director of Nursing is responsible for ensuring that the policy is disseminated throughout the division and that the required monitoring and audit are undertaken, with the resources provided to support this.
Lead Physiotherapists

Lead  Physiotherapists  are  responsible  for  ensuring  that  all  staff  within  the respiratory wards complies with the content of this document and for taking action when  this  is  not  the  case.  The  Lead  Physiotherapists  will  make  sure  that  all necessary training is provided.
Lead Nurses

Lead Nurses are responsible for ensuring that all staff within the respiratory wards complies with the content of this document and for taking action when this is not the case. The Lead Nurses will make sure that all necessary training is accessed by the team and assist the Lead Physiotherapists with rolling out the training.
Medical Staff
Medical staff will decide which patients may be appropriate for self proning based on the indications as outlined in this document
Senior Sisters/Nursing Staff

The senior sister in charge is accountable for the safe care and management of patient on the ward. They are therefore responsible for ensuring that all staff within the ward complies with this document and for implementing a system to provide assurance that this is the case.
All registered nursing staff  and physiotherapists will be responsible for the following:
All grades of nursing staff working in the respiratory wards must follow this guideline when patients are self proning.

All grades of nursing staff is required to watch the video on how to prone and sign to say they have seen it. If they feel they require hands on practical training they need to let their senior member of staff know/ Lead nurse or physiotherapist.

Additional training will be provided by the senior respiratory physiotherapists and the senior respiratory nursing staff. It is the nurses responsibility to ensure the bed side emergency equipment is checked and in working order at the beginning of the shift.
Key Elements of Policy / Guideline Background.

The prone position alters the mechanics and physiology of gas exchange to result consistently in improved oxygenation. The improvement of oxygenation during prone ventilation is multifactorial. Prone positioning improves gas exchange by improving the ventral-dorsal trans-pulmonary pressure difference, reducing dorsal lung compression, and improving lung perfusion. Increased functional residual capacity (FRC) has also been proposed. Changes in the distribution of extravascular lung water and secretions may also play a role. (Appendix 1).

Proning as a modality of treatment has been studied since 1974 and since then has become popular as it improves hypoxemia in 70% of cases (3,4). In recent years the PROSEVA (5) trial has shown mortality benefit but this was in ITU settings. This trial has increased interest in early proning.

The APRONET study (6) showed that 32.9% of patients with severe ARDS who received prone ventilation, showed low complication rates and significant improvements in terms of oxygenation and driving pressure. This again was in ITU settings.

A meta-analysis of 11 randomized controlled trials studying the efficacy and safety of prone positioning in acute respiratory distress syndrome showed that ventilation in the prone position significantly reduced overall mortality(by 33.7%) in patients with severe acute respiratory distress syndrome(7). Sufficient duration of prone positioning was significantly associated with a reduction in overall mortality.

The prone position may prove beneficial in cases of hypoxemic respiratory failure, even in awake patients, by avoiding mechanical ventilation and ventilator- associated complications. A retrospective study showed that prone ventilation was feasible and improved oxygenation in non-intubated, spontaneously breathing patients with Acute Respiratory Failure (8).

Another recent multicentre study which studied the efficacy and safety of early prone positioning combined with HFNC or NIV in moderate to severe ARDS showed early application of prone positioning with HFNC, especially in patients with moderate ARDS and baseline SpO2 > 95%, may help avoid intubation (9).

The conscious patient proning procedure is safe, inexpensive but requires co- operation from the patient. On analysis of studies on proning shows important points to organise the pronation process. Thus this protocol aims to keep it simple and effective by implementing checklist to standardize the process and make the procedure safe.

Prone ventilation in ARDS helps by reducing atelectasis in injured lung, reduce pleural pressure gradients and restore aeration to dorsal lung segments (3) thus prone is used as a rescue strategy for severe hypoxia and all the work focused on improving gas exchange.
Which areas can facilitate conscious patient self proning
Self proning should only be carried out in the respiratory wards where patients can be managed by a respiratory trained multi – disciplinary team.
Who can self-Prone
The patient must be able to follow commands and be able to turn themselves and turn themselves back.
Can prone if requiring 28% oxygen or more.
A discussion needs to have taken place between the doctor, physiotherapist reviewing the patient and nurse caring for the patient to assess the suitability of proning.
See Intensive care flow chart for full details. (Appendix 1)
An entry must be made in the patient's notes showing rationale, who agreed and what time they proned. The LocSSIP (Appendix 3) is to be completed.
Advice must be given to the patient about how and when they can turn back.
Documentation
The LocSSIP procedure safety checklist: Conscious Proning on Respiratory wards form must be completed and placed in the patients' medical records.
Patient proned Laminate completed and placed on door outside of room or bay and over bed if patient in a bay. ( Appendix 4)
The daily prone sheet is to be completed by healthcare staff caring or repositioning the patient. (Appendix 5)
Provide patient with patient proning leaflet (Appendix 6)

Patient observations – Monitor oxygen saturations for 15minutes after each position change to ensure oxygen saturation has not decreased. Continue to monitor oxygen saturations as per the National Early Warning Score (NEWS) (Appendix 1)
Training Requirements
All nursing staff to watch video on returning patient to supine from prone in event of medical emergency. Register to be signed by staff member and held by the ward manager.
Any additional training required (as deemed necessary by nursing/medical/ physiotherapy staff) will be provided by the physiotherapy team on the ward.
Monitoring and Audit
Outlined  below  is  the  Trust's  process  of  monitoring  compliance  with,  and  the effectiveness of the document's main points.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Signed training sheets kept by ward managers
Ward managers, PEF's, Senior Respiratory Physiotherapist, Matrons, Lead Respiratory CNS

data.text: Approval and Implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by CAG, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policies and guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform all respiratory staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality Impact Assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 7)

Appendix 6: Patient proning leaflet for patients
Proning information for patients
What is proning?
Proning is when you lie on your front, in the ‘prone position'.
Why is prone positioning important?
Some patients can develop problems with their lungs, making it difficult to receive enough oxygen.
Laying a patient on their front can help improve the flow of oxygen into all parts of the lung.
Prone positioning can decrease mortality in patients with conditions such  as  early  stage  pneumonia,  acute  lung  injury,  Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome or COVID-19.
How do I do it?
Turn onto your front, bend one arm to 90 degrees, and keep your other arm by your side. Turn your head towards the arm that is bent (see picture).
Pillows can be placed under the head, stomach and ankles for comfort. Physiotherapists/nurses will assist you the first time you
prone.

data.url: MSEGL-20005 MSE Self proning in the conscious patient with Covid19 1.0.006.png

data.text: How long should I do it for?
It is recommended that you alternate you position every 1 – 2 hourly as comfort allows. It is recommended that you alternate between prone, side lying and high sitting.
It is recommended that patients prone for 12-16 hours in a 24 hour period. This can be broken up into shorter periods both during the day and when sleeping.
When you have lunch you will need to have a light meal, and do not prone for 2 hours after eating.
Are there any risks with proning?
You may develop swelling to the face and the eyes, but this is common and will settle down once you are on your back.
You will be monitored whilst you are in this position, however if you are in pain or have difficulty breathing, let a member of staff know.
Guideline For Self Proning in the Conscious Patient With COVID-19 / MSEGL20005/ 1.0
